overview.short: Saccharomyces cerevisiae is a budding yeast widely used in baking and brewing and occasionally isolated as an opportunistic pathogen in clinical settings.
overview.clinical_context: May be recovered from bloodstream or sterile sites in immunocompromised patients, central lineâ€“associated infections, or following probiotic/yeast exposure; also found as coloniser/contaminant.

species_markers.notes: Helps separate Saccharomyces from urease-positive yeasts such as Cryptococcus.
Consistent fermenter; CO2 production may be noted explicitly.
Fermentation-associated CO2 production can support Saccharomyces-like fermentative yeast.

common_confusions.reason: Highly similar phenotypically; routine biochemical tests often cannot reliably distinguish at species level.
Often treated as a strain/variant within the S. cerevisiae group; many ID systems report as S. cerevisiae.
Overlapping yeast colony morphology; Candida more often forms pseudohyphae and has different assimilation profiles.

when_to_question_identification: If urease is positive or capsule is present, reconsider Cryptococcus rather than Saccharomyces.
If prominent pseudohyphae are described, consider Candida-like yeasts rather than Saccharomyces.
If species assignment is based only on colony morphology without MALDI-TOF or sequencing, treat species-level call as low certainty.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Preferred routine method for yeast genus/species identification; improves confidence vs morphology alone.
Definitive species-level identification within Saccharomyces when clinically significant.
Supports exclusion of Cryptococcus (typically urease positive) when yeast is recovered from sterile sites.
